channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [TIKA-3331] Return a more informative error when trying to parse encrypted ODT
item.description:
When parsing a PDF or ODF encrypted file, Tika returns a long, cryptic error message. A more informative message would be useful for the user - at least mention the encryption, and perhaps the algorithm used?

 

I enclose a fabricated example, but real-world examples can be found in a similar issue for the JHOVE tool: https://github.com/openpreserve/jhove/issues/640

 

The error log obtained:

 
Apache Tika was unable to parse the document
at /home/bertrand/Téléchargements/Toponymic guidelines_Instituto geografico nacional_2011.pdf.
The full exception stack trace is included below:

item.summary: Return a more informative error when trying to parse encrypted ODT

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Many parsers will return http://tika.apache.org/1.25/api/org/apache/tika/exception/EncryptedDocumentException.html if they are asked to parse an Encrypted or Password Protected file for which no http://tika.apache.org/1.25/api/org/apache/tika/parser/PasswordProvider.html was given / the password from that was wrong.

However, this looks like a bug in the PDF parser - can you share which PDF you used to trigger the null pointer?

Thank you for your answer. I was probably influenced by JHOVE behavior, because I noticed this error only with the GUI. I have just checked the same files with the command line, Tika does not return any error and is even able to retrieve text and metadata despite the encryption.

So I guess this is just a bug with the GUI?

Almost certainly a GUI bug from what you describe, but possibly also a Parser bug as well! If you could point us to one triggering PDF file, that'd help us check + hopefully fix

In general, in terms of errors and exceptions, we have https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/TIKA/ErrorsAndExceptions to document what parsers should aim for. However, due to limitations in the underlying libraries / tools used, and sometimes just a lack of volunteer time, not every parser follows the best practice fully!

This PDF https://github.com/openpreserve/format-corpus/raw/master/pdfCabinetOfHorrors/encryption_noprinting.pdf returns the kind of error when trying to open it with the GUI, and the enclosed `encrypte.odt` also.

Thank you again for the additional info!
Confirmed GUI bug.  I know I fixed this in main.  Let me confirm that I fixed it in the upcoming 1.26...  Sorry.

>despite the encryption

Um... BE CAREFUL with this interpretation.  IIRC, PDFs can have a creator password and a user password.  Separately, PDFs can be "encrypted" with an empty string.  Tika will not throw an EncryptedDocumentException if the password is the empty string.  We should however tell you in the metadata whether or not the PDF was "encrypted".  If we don't, please let us know.

Also, note that Tika's default behavior is to ignore access permissions.  PDFs can have an access permission flag that says "please don't extract text from me" or even "please don't extract text from me unless it is for accessibility."  You can configure Tika to throw an exception for either of these, but, again, you'll get this information in our metadata.

 

Especially for digipres and people who love files, I strongly encourage the use of the -J and maybe -t on the commandline or the /rmeta endpoint to get the fullest metadata...these both use the RecursiveParserWrapper.

 

If you're just jamming stuff into a search engine and you don't care about a bunch of things, our legacy xhtml/text should be good enough for you.

Thanks Tim, this is very helpful. I wasn't aware of these protections as being just warning flags. Tika 1.25 seems to work fine on encrypted PDFs, and mentions it in the metadata.

Nevertheless, Tka 1.25 still raises an error when submitting the password-protected ODF "encrypte.odt" both with GUI and CLI. Here comes the error:

Exception in thread "main" org.apache.tika.exception.TikaException: XML parse error
at org.apache.tika.parser.xml.XMLParser.parse(XMLParser.java:81)
at org.apache.tika.parser.odf.OpenDocumentMetaParser.parse(OpenDocumentMetaParser.java:201)
at org.apache.tika.parser.odf.OpenDocumentParser.handleZipEntry(OpenDocumentParser.java:229)
at org.apache.tika.parser.odf.OpenDocumentParser.handleZipFile(OpenDocumentParser.java:210)
at org.apache.tika.parser.odf.OpenDocumentParser.parse(OpenDocumentParser.java:165)
at org.apache.tika.parser.CompositeParser.parse(CompositeParser.java:280)
at org.apache.tika.parser.CompositeParser.parse(CompositeParser.java:280)
at org.apache.tika.parser.AutoDetectParser.parse(AutoDetectParser.java:143)
at org.apache.tika.cli.TikaCLI$OutputType.process(TikaCLI.java:210)
at org.apache.tika.cli.TikaCLI.process(TikaCLI.java:507)
at org.apache.tika.cli.TikaCLI.main(TikaCLI.java:150)
Caused by: org.xml.sax.SAXParseException; lineNumber: 1; columnNumber: 1; Content is not allowed in prolog.
at org.apache.xerces.util.ErrorHandlerWrapper.createSAXParseException(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.util.ErrorHandlerWrapper.fatalError(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLErrorReporter.reportError(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLErrorReporter.reportError(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLErrorReporter.reportError(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLScanner.reportFatalError(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLDocumentScannerImpl$PrologDispatcher.dispatch(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.scanDocument(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.parsers.XMLParser.parse(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.parsers.AbstractSAXParser.parse(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.jaxp.SAXParserImpl$JAXPSAXParser.parse(Unknown Source)
at org.apache.xerces.jaxp.SAXParserImpl.parse(Unknown Source)
at java.xml/javax.xml.parsers.SAXParser.parse(SAXParser.java:197)
at org.apache.tika.utils.XMLReaderUtils.parseSAX(XMLReaderUtils.java:505)
at org.apache.tika.parser.xml.XMLParser.parse(XMLParser.java:75)
... 10 more
Nice catch!  Looks like we have to do a bit more processing on the manifest.xml.

This is now fixed in branch_1x and main.  However, there's a bit of a catch (no pun intended).  If you handle the file as a stream, neither the JDK's ZipInputStream nor Commons Compress ZipArchiveInputStream can read the file because there's a descriptor on one of the streams, so you'll get a zip exception, not an EncryptedDocumentException.

 

The full fix for this problem would be to cache the stream, catch the exception, use ZipSalvager to save to file and on we go.  This is beyond the scope of this issue.  Adding decryption to openoffice files is also beyond this ticket.  Please open a new issue or, better, a PR if you need either of these capabilities.  Reference for the zip issue when streaming: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ODFTOOLKIT-402
Thank you BertrandCaronUnable to render embedded object: File (  Please let us know what else you find) not found.
